Name: OOP vs Procedural Programming
Key Points / Tips: OOP models real-world with objects; Procedural uses routines/functions. OOP offers encapsulation/inheritance/polymorphism – helps manage larger software better (modularity, reuse).

Name: Class vs Object
Key Points / Tips: Class is a blueprint/definition (e.g. Car class); Object is an instance of a class (e.g. a specific Car). Class defines attributes & methods, objects have actual values/state

Name: Encapsulation (Data Hiding)
Key Points / Tips: Encapsulation = bundling data with methods, and restricting direct access to some of an object's components. Achieved via access modifiers (private fields, public getters/setters)

Name: Abstraction (Interface)
Key Points / Tips: Abstraction = exposing only essential features and hiding implementation details. E.g. using an `List` interface without knowing internal code. Achieved via abstract classes or interfaces.

Name: Inheritance (IS-A)
Key Points / Tips: Inheritance = one class derives from another, reusing and extending behavior. Supports hierarchy (e.g. class Dog extends Animal). Enables code reuse; watch for Liskov Substitution (subclasses should be usable via base type).

Name: Polymorphism (many forms)
Key Points / Tips: "One interface, multiple implementations." **Compile-time polymorphism**: method overloading (same name, different params). **Run-time polymorphism**: method overriding in subclass (dynamic dispatch)

Name: Method Overloading vs Overriding
Key Points / Tips: **Overloading**: same method name, different signature (resolved at compile time). **Overriding**: subclass provides new implementation of base class method (runtime binding). Overriding needs inheritance; overloaded methods are in same class.

Name: Access Specifiers (public/private/etc)
Key Points / Tips: `public`: visible everywhere; `private`: visible only inside class; `protected`: visible in subclass (and same package in Java). Use private for encapsulation – internal fields hidden, access via public methods.

Name: Abstract Class vs Interface
Key Points / Tips: **Abstract class**: can have method implementations and state, but can't instantiate (may have abstract methods). **Interface**: purely abstract methods (Java 8+ can have defaults). Use interface for full abstraction/multiple inheritance of type; use abstract class for base with default behavior.

Name: Multiple Inheritance & Diamond Problem
Key Points / Tips: C++ allows multiple inheritance (class A, B -> class C inherits both). **Diamond problem**: ambiguity when two parent classes have a common base. Java avoids multiple inheritances of classes to prevent this. Interfaces in Java (no state) avoid diamond issues or use virtual inheritance in C++.

Name: Constructors and Destructors
Key Points / Tips: Constructor: special method to initialize new object (same name as class, called once on creation). Supports overloading. Destructor (in C++): called on object deletion to free resources. In Java/C#, garbage collector calls finalize (rarely used). Ensure deep copies if needed in copy constructors.

Name: SOLID Design Principles
Key Points / Tips: **S**ingle Responsibility, **O**pen/Closed, **L**iskov Substitution, **I**nterface Segregation, **D**ependency Inversion. These five guide good OOP design – e.g. one class = one purpose; favor composition over tightly-coupled dependencies

Name: Singleton Pattern (Single Instance)
Key Points / Tips: Ensure only one instance of a class globally (e.g. for config or caches). Typically implemented with a private constructor and a static `getInstance()` method. Beware multi-threading (use double-checked locking or `synchronized`).

Name: Shallow vs Deep Copy
Key Points / Tips: **Shallow copy**: copies field values as-is (pointers still refer to original object's data). **Deep copy**: duplicates all referenced objects too. Important for classes with pointers: define copy constructor & clone properly to avoid two objects sharing same sub-object
